question_body: I am married and have a 13 yr old daughter. I just lost my job. I have been working at this tech company for 15+ years. What should I do to make sure my family will be ok from financial perspective. I do have 7 months of paid leave and to find a job. Also, we live in IL and wondering if we can or should move to Colorado. What is a cost of living difference?
Would it be wise to move 401k plan from a aggressive growth to the safest thing I can before election?

We are on Baby Step 7.  We have $20,000 in our savings account as our emergency fund.  We think we should put half of it in an account that generates more interest.  What would you recommend?  Thank you, Deana Strudwick

Aloha , I’m 44 single on baby step 3 , full time 80K a year , 185,000 on a mortgage, shares in an apartment worth 200,000, my goal is to build an 1000sqft cottage on the land as my mortgage, asking for loan options to build ?
For my emergency fund, should i also include my insurance deductibles
I am looking for car insurance any advice l have geico but not sure if it's the best deal .
Smartvestor pro

Hi my name is Pedro 33 from Guatemala, with my wife we are on gazelle mode in step 2, we want to use all premium features of every dollar but it is only available on US. How can I use all premium features?
I have about $15K in not interest building debt. I have about $14K in stock market. Should I pull money and pay off debt?
How can I sell a financed vehicle that I'm upside down on? Would the title have a lien on the vehicle that would prevent the next owner from registering it?
Saving for a house purchase in 2-5 years. I'm thinking of putting the $30,000 we have for a down payment in a GIC, but I'm not sure if that's the best idea. What would you do?

I have 30k in credit card debt. Should I do a cash-out refinance to pay it off? My mortgage right now is 1800 with 18 years left. The new mortgage would be 2300 and go back to 30 years. What should I do?

Ramsey taught us the 7 Baby steps. What arte the next steps? Now that we have corrected the course, keep increasing wealth AND are helping others, 
how do you set up for retirement?

Hello, I wanted to get advice on my situation. I am upside down on my vehicle, and I don't think selling it is the best route for that reason. I was going to give it back to the finance company and take the repossession on my credit. If I keep the vehicle, I'm up to my neck. Is this the best route in my position?

my husband and I built a new home on our property (108 acres - which we own)  sadly my husband suddenly passed away before we closed on the new home.. we were both retired.. my income is unknown at this time I am retired (I do get my pension and will receive half of his plus a portion of his disability from and  his military pay)  My question is should I invest a portion of his life insurance or put it all against the new house mortgage of ?    I am also a veteran and qualify for a VA mortgage.
My company offers an employee stock purchase plan. Is this something to consider or would it be basically buying a single stock which I know Dave is against. Thanks for any advice.
Should i save for college first or start my emergency fund? I'm 17 with no debt, a job and a paid off car. Planning to go to college in 2 years

Hello, I am 27 years old. My partner and I have a 1-year-old and a 3-year-old. We only have $10,200 in debt combined, which is just an auto loan. We want to get this paid off as soon as possible but are also not looking to use our small $3,000 emergency fund. I am struggling with allocating extra funds towards the debt while paying $1,580 a month in daycare payments. After taxes, we both combined only make $5,000 a month. So by the time we pay for necessities and daycare, it feels super tight. Any advice?

I live in New Hampshire and I am selling a house that was left to by my grandparents being I am the only surviving person in the will. The estate has been settled. I am wondering how I should set aside for taxes from the sale and if I use it to pay down my own mortgage does that help lessen the taxes?
We have been told we should sign our home over to our children now to avoid problems when we die. Is this true and should it be just one who will be our executor or all 4 kids?

My husband and i are moving in with some friends temporarily to catch up on some bills after I was out of work for several weeks due to surgery and illness. He just got a higher paying job and i started back up with my business and it is slowly picking up. Should we pay off our car loan during this time or should we save up for a house down payment?
What is the fastest way to save up for down payment?

My kids college funds are fully funded and I want to start roth 401ks for my kids. We have a small business that I can employee the kids through. But my wife is dead set against it. She thinks it would be spoiling the kids. We won't miss the money in any way.

On the personal side, I am debt-free other than my house. On the business side I have two bank loans. The balance on one is $37,876 and the balance on the other is $39,417. One is a note for 2 carpet cleaning vans and equipment. Both roughly 50% of the way through their expected lives. The other is just one van in equipment with roughly 90% of its expected life remaining. Since they are so close in balance and interest rate which would you recommend paying off first?
I am 65 years old what life insurance policy should I purchase to ensure my wife will be taken care of?

I (29) am currently debt free besides my house (~255k mortgage). Collectively our family makes ~180k per yr. We have about 105k cash, 150k in 401ks. Nothing in a 529 for our only child, we plan on having a second soon. I have a life goal of buying some land (5 to 20 acres) and using it for conservation/restoration rather than to farm or make money off of. Looking for advice on what steps I should be taking financially to eventually get to the point where I can buy a few acres of land.
In reference to the recommended mortgage payment of 25% or less of your net pay, does this include utilities, Property Taxes, and hoa fees?
I own my home and I'm needing a loan to pay off debt and get caught up but don't wanna sink myself.

I could really use some advice. Me and my husband have acquired a good amount of credit card debt/medical bills. We have one vehicle that is completely paid off and we would be able to profit around 20,000 for. We are thinking about selling and paying off that debt but that‚Äôs leaves us with one car that we still owe about 27,000 on. In my opinion, being free from this debt and the payments that it acquires every month would be worth it. I would really like to get some opinions beforehand.
Struggling to make mortgage payment and I am now behind. Should I let them foreclose or what?
My husband passed last August 2022 and we had a house that was about paid off. If i pay this house off how will it affect my taxes?

Hello, my husband and I are currently in baby step two. We both have student loans that we are currently trying to pay off. My husband's student loans are broken up into six smaller loans each with their own amount totaling $18,215.00 (three loans of about $2000, two loans of about $3000 and then one bigger one of $6,200). My loans are grouped as two bigger loans totaling $17,853 about $8900 and $8800 each. Currently, we are paying the minimum payment on my group of student loans, and throwing all of our extra money toward his, knocking them out by each group starting from the smallest amount and working up to the largest. Is this correct even though technically, the total amount of his student loans is more than the total amount of mine? Thank you so much for taking the time to read this!

My wife and I live overseas (UK) where I work as a contractor for the US government.  We do not have a residence in the United States but don't want to miss out on growing wealth through owning real estate. We have enough to put down (25%) on an investment property and keep it within the limits of what Ramsey suggests (15 year, under 25% of our take home pay). We are debt free and wondering if we should be long distance landlords as we will probably be overseas for at the next 5-years. We could just continue to stack cash and make the downpayment higher. Is this something that you guys would suggest since we don't own any real estate? Currently, our money sits in a high-yield savings account for this reason.
I inherited a paid off home. I am thinking about selling  it  and using that money to start a self storage business but not sure where to start. What do you recommend?

Hello, I am 28 years old and have a baby on the way with my partner. We are not married yet. I work with the county in San Diego, CA. They offer a 401(a) with no match, a traditional 457, and a Roth 457. There is no match; however, there is a pension offered, and I automatically have 7.09% deducted before taxes each pay period. My gross income is $124,791.40 annually (just myself). I have individual stocks invested with a total value of $41,625.50. What would you recommend I do for investments?

Hi, I recently graduated from dental school. The base salary at my first job is $235,000 per year. I owe a total of $260,000 in loans. I'm single and live in a state with no state income tax. Assuming I prioritize paying off my loans as soon as possible, how much would you recommend I spend per month on all living and fun expenses? How would you budget? Should I hold off on investments?
Hi. I have roughly $21k in student loan debt. I am 35 years old and just want it gone. I currently have $95k in 401k. Is it a bad idea to take out a "loan" against my 401k to just pay this off?

I have a $355k mortgage at 6.25% and a $50k 401k loan at 8.25%. I have all my money in one account, about $169k, and will be getting a refund of $168k from the student settlement Sweet v. Cardona. Which one should I pay first?
Should I hold rollover funds in cash because of an expected market correction

My mother passed away, and my stepfather wants to contact the bank and ask about foreclosing on the house, closing up shop, and returning to his home state (Wyoming). I would rather sell the house and contractually use any profit to pay off debt to family members, creditors, etc. I was thinking a power of attorney would allow me to conduct the transaction on his behalf. I would hate to lose all my mother's investment in the home. The house is in AZ, and I'm in CA. Any suggestions?
My 6-year-old will be inheriting around $40,000 in the next few months. Where do we put the money so that it grows but is also safe?

I'm 24 years old and just got a full time job that pays 25/hr, I have $13,520 in student loans, $2,500 in dental bill debt, and $2,800 in credit card debt from my parents who opened a card in my name. I pay $600 in rent and utilities each month. I work remote so I don't have a car but I would like to get one  asap. How should I go about paying off these debts? Where should I start and how much should I budget each month to each debt?
need attorney for will/trust

My Husband and I have no debt, emergency savings for months, and $12,000 saved up for when we need to replace our car. Our next goal is to be able to buy a house. Should we just be putting the money we are able to save in a savings account or invest it to take out in a couple of years for a house?

I am 50, I have made some terrible decisions with the choices I had in front of me and I will be paying for them for a long time.  I have 118,000 in student loans, I owe about 34,000 on the house, I have 26,000 in credit card debt, I owe just under 4500 on my car.  I have about 60,000 in loans.  Things are not going so great with my husband and I have got to get out of the house with my 14 year old or I am going to crack working 2 very high demand jobs with very little help from my husband.  He struggles with mental health issues that have steadily declined since we got married 12 years ago and has never been able to keep more than a menial part time job.  I am on babystep 2 and will be doing that for years if I am not able to increase my income.  My practice is finally starting to build with 2 to 4 new patients per week.  I am just about to crack with trying to do everything and I have no idea what to do with finances or how to get my own space.  I have thought about trying to find an old RV or tiny house to put on the property.  I don't have the money to just rent another household.  I am just at a loss.  I do have the 1,000 dollar emergency fund.  I have about 3,000 left from income tax return for last year.  I have been hanging on to it because my income is all over the place.  I have 17,000 in our main business account and another 5,000 in another account where our copays go.  My SBA loan was 24000 originally, and I have no idea where I am right now with that.  My house was used as collateral.  I am sure I could come pretty close to paying off the SBA, but again, the insurance payments are not regular so I need a good level of cushion to make sure I am able to pay a few months of overhead if something comes up.  First things first, I have got to get away from my husband for awhile.  I just don't know how to do that.  Sorry, this is a little therapy, and a little financial.  But any guidance would be good.

Hello, I inherited my grandfathers house. Who left the whole estate to my mom. And both of us are unclear on the right way to go about this. What taxes will I have after I put this in my name. And I plan on living here for about 10 years or so. Thank you.
I have 2 older children and 2 younger children.  My parents are getting older and my husband's job as well as mine are facing industry-wide challenges.  I am not sure where to start prioritizing.

My husband and are on baby step 2 with about 1500$ left.  I have a car with 250k miles and will need something soon.  As we start step 3 of saving 3-6 months of expenses do we take that money when we're ready to buy a car and use it as down payment? Or just try to buy as sensible as possible without making a huge down payment, try to get a low monthly payment and just attack it the next year or two?

I'm a 17-year-old who recently graduated from high school. I'll be 18 in less than 4 months and entering college in the fall. The only financial step I have taken so far was creating a high school checking account. Eventually, I'll be converting the account into a college checking account, but I would like to know what I can do to be financially independent by the time I graduate from college. Should I apply for a credit card and build credit, invest some money I earn from my part-time job, etc.?

Hi. I am a 23-year-old who just got married, and I am going into Physician Assistant School. My wife is a school teacher making around $40,000 a year. We have $10,000 set aside for emergency funds. PA school will cost roughly $90,000. We have a tight budget and don't go out, only spending on essentials. Is there any advice on how we can pay off the school as soon as possible? Also, is there any way I could start investing now? We try to put $100 aside each month and add to the emergency fund. Thanks.

I am a 26 year old that is debt free. Purchased my first home last year for 265,000 with 20% down. My household income is around 175,000. I have about 150,000 in savings (bank, and stock) and 80k in my 401k. My question is do I use any of that 150,000k of savings to pay a chunk of my house off. Keep me mind my mortgage rate is only 3.2%.

I am 61. My 20 yr term life insurance policy is expiring. We have no debt. My husband has a 100,000.00 life policy with a long term care addendum.  Should I get another life policy or just a long term care policy?
Hi  I am self employed and have a Business loan of 272,000 should I pay this off before I put money into my retirement fund and emergency account?

We let a student loan with $13k left go into default 3 years ago. Two years ago, we called AES to find out how to get current, and they told us they sold it to another lender but couldn't tell us who. We followed up 2 weeks ago, and they said the same thing: they sold it 2 years ago. We know it will cause problems eventually, so we are saving to pay it off when it does come back to us. With no contact and no report on our credit score, is there anything else we can do to find out where it is?

Should I sell the home I own, or should I rent it? Is passive income that may appreciate better than reinvesting? I am a young war widow with three young children. Side note: I bought the home for $415k in 2019; I can sell it now for around $750k. They are building 10k more houses in this area, and the lake is dry. I am not sure it will appreciate much higher than it already has. Thanks in advance.

If I want to pay off $3,400 in credit card debt (the only debt besides my home), would you recommend that I suspend my offerings to organizations I give to monthly for a total amount of approximately $350 (not including tithes)? I haven't thought of it before, but I wanted an opinion…
We have a camper that we owe $35k on the best offer we have gotten is $30k should we sell and finish paying the loan or hold on to it and keep paying for the camper
Should I cash out $150K from my IRA (knowing it will be taxed) in order to pay off my mortgage?

I am 56 years old.  I collect a pension since I was 47 years old.  In 11 months, I will be collecting a 2nd pension.  I currently work 2 jobs, but in the 11 months I will be dropping to just 1.  I have 2 IRA's with a value of $207,000.00.  Our mortgage balance in $199,000.00 @ 3.5% and our HELOC balance is 43,000.00 @ 8%.  We have no other debt.  My wife works part time and averages about $3,000.00 net a month.  Our combined net income per month is an average of $12,500.00 with a monthly living expense of roughly $6,500.00.  That includes housing and every thing else, with the exception of savings deposits.  

My question is this, should I focus on adding to my IRA's or paying off the HELOC and mortgage?  We enjoy dinners out and we budget throughout out the year to tip our servers very generously as well as help out random people who may need a meal.  We spend about $1,500.00 a year +- on generosity.

We follow your baby steps, but I'm not sure if having 2 pensions changes the landscape at all.

We look forward to your responses. Thank you

I am 22 years old married with no children. My my husband and I have been debt free for the first two years of our marriage, but he started Chiropractic school this summer and we will now be incurring about $45,000 a year in debt ($10,000 a quarter. and he is in quarter 2 of 14) for the next 3.5 years. By the time he grduates, if we only take out loans for his tuition, we will have about $250,000 in debt (8% interest). I started working full time 3 months ago after graduating college just in time for him to start school. I make $3,000 a month and if we budget well, we can live off of it each month. We also have about $12,000 in savings. We would really like to start our family within the next six months or so, so I would be able to work for another year or so. My question is, would it be the worst thing ever to take out more loans to live off of in order for me to be a stay at home mom? We don't want to wait any longer to have children but my husband couldn't possibly work right now with how intense his schooling is. We aren't crazy spenders. We plan on moving in with my parents after my husband graduates so that we can pay down the loans quickly. We just really want to start our family, and my personal conviction with children (& my husbands) is to fully raise them at home and not in a daycare (which we couldn't afford anyway). We just need some wisdom:) We believe children are a blessing from God and we really don't want to wait anymore.

A feature where the replies given to questions should be screened. I have seen a few responses such as “I understand feeling guilty! Good luck…,” which is not content worthy. I think before responses are automatically posted, responses should be screened to ensure posts are aligned with Ramsey principles. That way questions and responses are not just flooding the App.
I'm 24 y/o who is getting out of the national guard. I have a TSP Roth with 8k. Do I leave it in there or roll it over to an IRA? I also have a 403b (IPERS). I am on baby step three.

My husband took out a reverse mortgage when he became injured on the job. It's a variable rate also. Double whammy! I wasn't of age and wasn't a co-borrower. I am listed as heir to the house. We only owed $100,000 on the house. Now it's up to $300,000 and counting, with a whopping $1,000 a month interest charge. I'm working many jobs and have paid down my debt. We have adult children in the home helping with expenses in a mother-daughter situation. I'm now 65 and can be placed on the mortgage. I was told.

If we have a business, and are trying to tithe on that- how would you recommend tithing.  Based on the income after expense? Or solely on income received? We are a construction company and have to pay sub contractors.  Therefore our true profit is not seen until we've actually paid out to the subs.  Should we tithe off the difference?

Single income home bringing in around 7-8000/month. 170k in debt between a truck, camper, student loans and other misc bad debts. In baby step 2. I have been hoping to be a travel nurse for years; part of that debt is for a truck and a camper I bought 2.5 years ago to live that dream. However, there has always been one reason or another why I can't live my dream. i.e, dogs, kids, spouse. My spouse is a stay at home dad to our 4 and 6 year old, and has been for a couple of years due to lack of childcare options. I want to sell our house and take a contract away from the freezing winters of MN, homeschool our kids and give them a life of adventure, where I am not working 60 hours a week between multiple jobs. It's either that, or continue with this debt snowball which will take me 4-5 years working as much as I am, to live in a house I have always hated and missing out on so much of my children's lives since I am gone most of the time.. Am I just being selfish by finally asking for something for me? Is it even a good idea to sell a house with my interest rate being so low (2.75%). I just don't know how to approach this topic with him as he seems extremely hesitant to uproot our lives as it "would be a lot of work".

I’m currently married but separation/divorce is likely. We live in SC and my spouse works and has income of $76k gross income and I’m disabled receiving approximately $2700 mo in SSDI & fed employee disability benefits. I’m 53 yrs old and will not be able to return to work. We have 1 child age 10. Our house was purchased at $500k in 2019 but is currently worth $820+k and we owe $200k. Mortgage payment of $1600 mo in my spouse’s name only. However my father also lives with us and his name is also on the deed (right of survivorship)  which he plans to leave to me as inheritance (he’s currently 78 yrs old). Our cars are paid for (over 10 yrs old) , combined credit card debt of  $50k,$3k in medical expenses. No other debt.  My spouse has state retirement est $50k and I have federal est $30k. No savings , not even $1k EF. Our monthly credit card payments are about $2k mon. I have separate property valued at $500k. My spouse and I cannot afford to live in separate homes and stay in our current school district. We can’t seem to work together to get the debt snowball rolling. Our current home interest rate is 2.4%. We have looked into cash out refinance mortgage to complete a basement apartment that is partially finished now and that would also consolidate all our high interest rate cc debt. This would give us $100k cash. This would change our int rate to 8% w/ mortgage $3k month but would allow us to “nest” while living separately and wouldn’t displace my father.  Or would you advise selling the house & paying off all debt, knowing that relocation to different school district and possibly state would have to occur?  This would also likely mean that 1 parent would have primary custody with the other only having visitation. I guess a 3rd option would be for me to sell my separate property (vacant land in another state)  and pay off all debt and pay for basement renovation. With a divorce looming I prefer not to do that.  The current house deed would not allow me to recoup that money in the event we have a contentious divorce. Also, once sold, I understand that the money from the sale of my separate property converts to joint ownership.

Dear Mr. Ramsey, 
I have been following your advice for years.  I retired at age 70 after 49 years of nursing in CA. I started collecting SS when I turned 70.  I bought low and sold high.  Then utilized the 1031 exchange to purchase my current home in Fayetteville AR where I retired Last year, I sold another rental in Texas and purchased a fixer upper two miles from my home so I can manage it myself.  This month, I sold my house in CA and plan to pay off the rental with part of the proceeds.  I am now dept free with a little cash in the bank. I am budgeting to live on social security. Car is paid off, no mortgages, and no credit card dept. I am fully insured with warranty insurance. I have a life insurance policy I started at age 30 when my ex walked out the door in favor of a younger model Kids have no college dept thanks to me. My money is being managed my financial planner. I have a great CPA. What do you recommend I do next? Assuming a tornado doesn't blow my roof off. The rental needs a new roof. I am thinking metal. I just don't know. have survived 18 months of retirement with what was in my piggy bank. With the rental paid off and everything but a new roof. I really have no big expenses. I want to keep my hard-earned money out of the clutches of the government. That is my primary goal at this point. Advice?

I’m currently retired drawing a pension. I am also 100% disabled and drawing a VA pension. I will be drawing a military pension starting in January. The only monthly expense I have now is a mortgage approximately $815 a month with 127,000 still on the mortgage, I have 100,000 and savings 25,000 and a CD and about 150,000 and various IRAs and mutual funds. I plan to build a house on some land. I am about to inherit and move west of Nashville into West Tennessee I am trying to ensure I do not have to take a loan to build the house which I am guessing will be around $250-$300,000  Taxes on my present home are rated at 252,000. I have two vehicles both are paid off my monthly income from pensions presently is around 6200 and in January should increase to about 8000 to 8500. what is your suggestion?

I am currently a college student working a part-time job with a very irregular income. Some months, I bring in over $1,100, and others, I am lucky to bring home $500. I currently have $24,000 cash saved from prior summer's work, but I don't enjoy using that money if possible as most of it is invested in non-retirement accounts. I currently spend about $1,200 a month on living and all other expenses. How do I budget based on this irregular income and feel okay using some of that nest egg I have saved up?

Both my husband and I are teachers. I plan to retire in 2025. Our take home pay will diminish roughly about $800-1100, which we are confident we can make up with side hustles. I make 83K a year. If I stay 1 more year it does not change my pension much since I have 30 yrs vested. We have 27K in credit cards. Should we go with a debt collection agency for that, should I work another year, or should we focus on snowball effect? On top of our life pension(which is solely what we are looking at for income and is $800-1100 less each month than now), he will eventually pull ss (he will be 65 in June I will be 59 in Feb), a 403B with about 60K and I will receive 14500 1x a year for 5.5 yrs (OPEB  from district).

I am currently a senior in college with $3,500 in cash saved, $21,000 in non retirement investments, and $9,500 in Roth IRA with no debt. I will be graduating in May 2025 and will be looking for a full-time career in sports management and event production. I currently have a girlfriend of a year and 8 months, who I plan to propose to in the next year. She will graduate in May of 2026, a year after me. She and I have discussed finances in the past and I have shown her the dangers of debt and how it can affect you for a long time in the future. She now is much more conscious about her money and spending habits, however, she will graduate a year later than me and will have approximately $30,000 in student loans and consumer debt. I know that finances do not combine until marriage, but I want to know how to best prepare for the future and transition from dating to marriage without anyone feeling jealous or guilty about money based on different starting points. With a full year's worth of income under my belt, I believe I will be able to save enough money to pay off all debts once we get married if that is what actually happens (Which I believe it 100% will). What is a good dollar amount to have saved ready to go for this big transition of my life over the next two or so years?
Debt free and 6months of emergency savings. Saving for a house

Hello,

My wife (33) and I (33) discovered Mr. Ramsey in 2018. We were following the steps and became debit free a year later. That’s when we stopped… we just lived our lives saving money but not putting it into retirement. We have 3 kids and life was great. Then 2020 came and the world became crazy. I made the choice to not get the needle that the army required so I was separated after 8 Years of service in 2022. So for the last 2 years we’ve hadn’t been working I’ve just been with my family making up fit the time I missed.  We had been living off our saving. Fast forward to June of this year and we bought land in Tennessee to start life again. All but 10k of what we had to our name went to the land and the rv we are currently living in. On top of that we stupidly got a loan to buy a truck to tow the trailer because I didn’t want to spend the 7k I was being quoted to get it towed. 
All was well until a few weeks ago when my 2 year old was diagnosed with leukemia. I had just got a job that I have since lost for missing so much time while I was on probation. So now my savings is all but gone plus I owe 35k on this truck and the credit cards are maxed at 35k. My only income now an only 33k yearly which I get from the va. We have decided to move back to Arizona to have support from family while my son gets his treatment for the next 2 plus years. I guess my question is what do I do with the land we currently live on? Do I sell it to cover the debit I have or do I keep it because it is paid off and in theory its value will go up with time?

Context
Married both 33 have 3 kids
35k in credit cards, 35k on a truck with worth 30k, and about 7k in savings.
Monthly income is 2700 with 2k in expenses.
Land value would be about 50k

I went from finally trying to live our dream of a homestead, to buried in debt and scared to death for my son in a matter of 4 months and I don’t know how to go about fixing this.

Thank you in advance and if I rambled I’m sorry, I’m a little scatter brained right now.

I'm 61 and my wife is 57 and we just adopted two teens Granddaughters.  We have a mortgage that has a balance of 208,000 that is valued at 355,000, a 7/1 arm that has 50,000 on it, and about 32,000 in Credit card debt.  Being the first mortgage is a 2.75 interest rate, i am thinking about getting just a Home Equity Loan to consolidate the 7/1 arm and credit card debt.  The 7/1 arm will have to be refinanced after the 7 years is done if I keep it.  Is this a bad idea being the Equity loan will be financed for 20 years?

Hello, I retired from the military last year and am receiving my retirement pay and disability pay. Unfortunately, I haven’t found a full time job with a purpose, and therefore have no way of starting a 401K. Is there another way you would suggest I start investing for a better and healthier retirement? 

Thank you.

We're thinking of selling our current home and buying another one outright so we don't need to worry about losing a roof over our heads. The property taxes in our current home are steep, and the new place would have much lower property taxes.

The way I was thinking about doing this is either a full or partial cash-out of our 401K. The problem here is the 10% penalty that I'd love to avoid. I'm going to work with my manager to try to stay employed to Jan 1st when the 55 rule will kick in and I don't get hit with the penalty.

But I'm also EXTREMELY concerned about how the upcoming election could introduce market volatility and destroy the value of my 401K. They might give me an option to take a severance package (it won't be more than the 10% early withdrawal penalty) if I don't stay until next year.

What do you think is the better option? Take the severance, collect unemployment, cash out of the 401K now to avoid the potential instability? Take a gamble on the market not going crazy, and try to stay employed until Jan 2025 and then tap into the 401K?

Also, this 55 rule has me so perplexed. Must I been employed during the calendar year I turn 55 (this would be 2025 for me) in order for the 55 rule to apply? What if I lose my job a few months shy at the end of this year? Would that mean too bad for me, and even when Jan 1st rolls around and I'm not employed I don't qualify for the 55 rule?

The plan of semi-retirement will be me doing contract work when I can get it, as well as odd jobs here and there, just to have some money coming in to cover living expense and property taxes.

P.S. My childhood friend Julie and her husband Brad appeared on your show a few years back, telling their success story. It was super inspirational!

Advice App Updates 🔔 

The team is overwhelmed by your participation this early. We feel we have a real opportunity to help people get the help they need and it would not be possible without you.

I wanted to provide some updates on what we have been up to and what is coming. 

1. Profiles - We launched the core profile. This is an opportunity to provide more context on who you are and where you are at on the Baby Steps. For our coaches, coordinators, and pros it's also a place to let people know how they can connect with you. If you are one of these folks and do not see a title on your profile please let me know. 

2. Vouches - We updated vouches to show who has vouched a reply. This was highly requested by you guys. Just click the vouches count and it will pop up! Vouch notifications in the app are in the near future as well, so less navigating back to see who vouched. As a reminder vouches are meant to signify a good answer that is aligned to Ramsey principles. 

3. Reactions - Another request from you guys, reactions are a way to thank, celebrate, or ask for more info. We are going to keep testing to figure out what these need to be. If you have any ideas around reactions please let me know!

4. Notifications - We are currently evaluating in app notifications. These would serve as a quick way to see who was replied to you, vouched your reply, or asked a question in a topic you care about. More to come on that as we explore.

I will continue to keep you guys updated and as always I would love to hear any feedback you have.

You can check out our full roadmap and request features here:
https://airtable.com/app1WA88NCyPBlJLV/shrv8xVdhNfxivCex

I am 43, currently in the process of a high conflict divorce.  My ex and I dated and lived together for 2 years before purchasing a home together in 10/26/2012. We both contributed to the earnest money, closing costs and the utilities and insurance were both in my name alone.  At the time, my ex’s credit score was significantly higher than mine. Our loan officer advised taking the mortgage out in my ex’s name alone vs both our names because without my name our interest rate was 3.5% vs 6% with my name.  So that is what we did.   This was the first home either of us had purchased.   What I didn’t understand at the time was that the mortgage and the deed/title were two separate things, I thought it was all wrapped up together.  The plan was always that my name would be added to the property once my credit score improved, however, my ex never followed through.  We were married in 8/2/2014.  So for the first 21 months that we owned the house we were not yet married.  My ex and I had an average marriage with ups and downs like every other couple, but we overall happily married.  So it was a complete shock when my ex pulled the old “running out to grab a quick drink” and never came home.  That was 5/21/23.  He went radio silent for almost a month.  My initial reaction was that something bad had happened to him, but about a week after he disappeared I was able to confirm that he was safe at his brother’s house.  On 6/16/23 I was emailed a divorce petition.  In the petition my ex is stating he has a non-marital claim to the house.  We finally have our day in court this Monday.
My ex has not lived in the house since 5/21/23, I have remained in the home and have been paying all of the housing costs.  I have a copy of our lease agreement from the apartment that we lived in prior to buying the house, emails between myself and the realtor we used, (my ex was not included in those), emails from the inspector addressed only to the realtor and myself, as well as proof that the utilities have always been in my name.  Will this be enough to invalidate his non-marital claim? Or is this a lost cause?

Christmas Blessings: Our family of 6 because homeless when we realized that the mold we discovered after removing ceiling tiles in a bedroom was causing severe medical issues for several of us. After a few days in a tent outside with 4 little kids, and exhausting all other options for temporary housing, we moved into a cheap hotel. We were in the middle of chapter 13 bankruptcy from a failed rental real estate business, and looking for a rental for ourselves for the first time in my life.

Our extended family could not take in a family of 6, and we felt lost. This is when God showed up. We eventually ended up in a shelter apartment for medically displaced 1 hour from our hometown. We were there for 2 months while looking desperately for housing in our hometown. During the time at the shelter, my cornea was scratched by an ER doctor. I was driving an hour each way meeting with agents not able to see in my one eye. I was taking eye drops each hour from the fungal infection in my eye around the clock, and were getting rejected by each agent we met.

Our church stepped up and drove me to my eye appointments. A friend opened up a GoFundMe and friends were generous. God got us through what seems like a never-ending nightmare. My kids learned how to work together, and what it means to live without a home. This created a heart for the homeless, and a generous spirit. 

God is so good.

I don't remember why, but my health insurance stopped (and also restarted, when I had JUST met my deductible) from being $0 a month to $650 a month on October 1, 2024. I have made one payment of $650 to pay October's. But I still owe November & December and although they say I still have insurance, they're not paying for anything and the bills are adding up VERY quickly. You see, I have Stage IV, metastatic breast cancer in 3 places in my spine and a spot on my 4th left rib. I just started treatment about 2 months ago. But I have to go get a port draw (bloodwork) every two weeks to see how my body is doing with treatment, where my levels are, etc. I also go and see my oncologist, get an infusion, and get hormone blockers every month. I'm up to $100,000 to pay for treatments and tests just since October. I've spoken with my ex-husband's accountant and she is supposed to be checking into filing an amendment to last year's taxes and filing mine (I pray). My problem is that I don't have health insurance paying for healthcare, although I am receiving care at insurance prices, so I'm grateful for that much. And although the IRS says I have no income, the federal government says that my divorce settlement is a gift each month, so I can't get any federal help with Medicaid, etc. So what do I do??? I also need to write out my will because of the cancer. I own my own home, a 2011 Terrain, have no debt except hospital/medical bills. I live very simply, but could still cut back on little things if I have to. I just need help with my medical situation. I'll also say that God is HUGE in my life and I know He provides, but sometimes He wants us to do something, too. I need to know what that is. I believe I have a Calling on my life and my home (which is a fixer-upper), but now that I have cancer, I don't know if I'm going to be around or if He's going to call me Home. I can see it going either way. I THINK He wants to keep me around because I'm learning sooooo MUCH in my Bible studying and what the Holy Spirit is speaking to me. But, I could be wrong. Things that seem sensible to us are not God's way of doing things. So maybe this health insurance thing is a test of faith and a test of me needing to ask for help/humility. I just need to know that I'm doing my part while I'm also trusting Him. Oh, I also can't file for Disability (I've tried) because of the "gift" my ex "gives" me each month. Along with the cancer, I also have Major Depressive Disorder with Panic & Anxiety, Type 2 Diabetes, Asthma, ADHD & OCD, that list goes on, too. The devil is charging at me from every direction. I've got my armor on but I'm trying to build fortified walls, also. Thank you, in advance, for any advice/help you can give. Also, I'd like to join one of your plans but I'm already behind with money, so I don't think that would be smart.

I recently signed with a debt consolidation company with a law firm. I had so much credit card and personal loan debt from helping my family and my children that I was getting nowhere. I was paying for it all each month, but the interest and debt was so high that I was just a hamster on a wheel. I was living paycheck to paycheck with no emergency fund or any type of savings. I figured going this route was better than filing bankruptcy. So essentially, I stop paying everything and then the law firm settles the accounts with the lenders for a lesser amount. I have to pay the consolidation company each month I think for four years for them to have the money to settle the debt, but it is one third of what I was paying monthly for all of the debt before, and it will save me about $50,000 total. I know this will hurt my credit, but I am hoping that it will be ok since I am paying them a settlement, and that I can rebuild my credit in a quicker time frame. I hope I made the right decision. I did not know what else to do. I was struggling to live. So now I am starting my financial journey with the baby steps, and I will not be taking on any debt ever again if I can help it. I am downloading the everydollar app, creating a budget, saving the $1,000 for the first step as fast as I can, and then plowing through the rest of the debt we have. I did not include my personal  line of credit or my care credit card. Those 2 are about $4700 together. Then, my wife has one credit card and a small student loan. She has really good credit so we did not include anything of hers so that one of us keeps a really good score. I am the sole provider. I am a RN so I make a very good annual salary. Without that huge debt, we will be able to accomplish a great deal I think. I guess I just want to get your opinion on everything. Do you think I am on the right track or was this a horrible decision? Do you have any suggestions that I should take into consideration. Thank you for your time.

I recently received this notification from our retirement management company at work. What does this exactly mean and do I do it all or a portion?

Beginning January 2, 2025, we’re pleased to announce that you’ll soon have the option to convert all or a portion of your before-tax 401(k) plan balance to a Roth account within the plan. This new feature is known as a “Roth in-plan conversion.”

Roth accounts are designed to combine the benefits of saving in your tax-deferred 401(k) plan, with the advantage of avoiding taxes on your money when you make withdrawals in retirement.*

A Roth in-plan conversion allows you to move money you have saved in an eligible workplace retirement plan into a designated Roth account within that plan.

They were told they’ve got all they’re getting from us, we gave all four $100,000 towards their homes. 
     Fast forward, my husband has early onset dementia. He’s had it about five years and is declining. I’m providing care for him at home so far and, I’m also caring for our 48 year old son that will more than likely be on hospice soon. 
     Our daughter is a true blessing. She has neurological issues and mild Aspergers. I have so many appointments for all of them and I’m to the point of exhaustion. I have to place my son and husband and put my health and our daughters health first now.

I’m paying about $2,500 per month for a private school and tutoring. We also private pay eye and dental care for her. I have a college account set up for her of $200,000 that’s in a stock portfolio and doing well. We have a protection trust we sat up years ago. Our daughter will be the beneficiary of our estate and we have everything protected.

     I feel heartbroken having to place my son and husband but, I’ve taken care of my son for eight years and my husband five. I’m emotionally and physically worn out and, my daughter needs a more happy home type environment, not a care facility to live in.

After years of therapy I am blessed to be able to walk unassisted now, but do have a home health aid for assistance. I also have a rare genetic bone disease and am on an extremely expensive treatment, so I rely on a Medicaid aged and disabled program for the home health and for extra help covering the costs of my medications. (just under 4 million a year) 

In early 2014, my husband went in for neck surgery. What was to have been an overnight stay ended up being 6 weeks in ICU for multiple complications and further surgeries. When he finally came home it was with a significant hypoxic brain injury. As we only had my small SSDI coming in, I first sold one vehicle to help keep us afloat. Then I did a hardship withdrawal of his 401K so I could continue to pay our mortgage and utilities. I applied for SSDI for him and thankfully he was approved pretty quickly. He passed away in 2017 from related complications. 

Income-wise I receive my SSDI and also a percentage of what my husband’s SSDI was as his disabled widow (SSWD) I recently started drawing one of his small pensions. I also work about 4 hrs per month doing light filing for a local business, which qualified me for a Medicaid Buy-In for Workers with Disabilities program. It lowered my monthly Personal Liability costs to maintain the secondary Medicaid costs significantly. 
I owe $30,000 on my mortgage at 2.8% and have one remaining credit card with a balance of $7K on it that I am paying extra on each month. I got the higher interest rate ones paid off first. My wife and I are both 49 working full time and we earn about  £125k ($155k) each so household £250k ($310k).

We’ve both been saving through our company pension for 25 years - company contributes 12% of our salary and we add 15%. This started at 12% + 6% but we’ve increased our personal contributions over time. I think we’ll have about £1M each in our pensions when we retire or maybe more …. I’ve not looked in ages.

Our home is worth £1.2M ($1.5M) and is fully paid off.

We both put £20k into shares ISAs every year although didn’t start this as early as I wish. Our portfolio is half in index trackers and half in funds I’ve picked. Total portfolio now about £800k ($1M).

I inherited my dads home which is worth about £900k ($1.1M) but this isn’t generating any income as my step mother is allowed to live there for ‘as long as she wants’ after my dads passing as per his wishes. This was only supposed to be a couple of years until she moved into one of her houses but she doesn’t seem to be focused on moving any time soon.

We do spend about £20k ($25k) per year on holidays and £24k ($30k) per year on school fees for our 12 year old daughter and we hope she continues to university. 

We have no debt. 
We have one paid off car that we paid £50k ($62k) cash for. Our second car is a Tesla on lease but this saves me on taxes as I pay the lease before tax through a company car scheme. Before tax this is £1k ($1.24k) per month but because of my income I’d be paying 60% tax on this money otherwise. Earning between £100k and £125k in the UK is a tax trap.

In summary, our family net worth is about £2.9m ($3.6m) plus a further £2m ($2.5m) in pensions. We earn £250k ($310k) pre-tax and we’re spending about £60k (€75k) per year.

So, what do we do? Keep saving, retire, spend more. I have no idea.

Hello Team Ramsey, I would like to provide some context about my situation. My name is Nick, and I married my high school sweetheart in 2010. Shortly after our marriage, we discovered that I was infertile, which was a significant blow to my wife, who had always envisioned having a large family. To address this longing, we decided to pursue foster care. Fast forward six years, and we ended up adopting all six of our foster children. This was not the path we initially anticipated for building our family, but it seems that God had a different plan for us. 

Amanda is a stay-at-home mom, a role that I believe is far more challenging than my own job as an operations manager at Valvoline. Our income is approximately $80,000 per year. Currently, I have a potential side business opportunity that could yield around $85,000 weekly. While this prospect could significantly alter our lives, I find myself feeling apprehensive—not about the deal itself, but about the impact that such wealth might have on us. I hold the belief that money does not equate to happiness, and I am reminded of the scripture in Mark 10:25, which states, "It is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter the kingdom of God." 

Am I wrong to hope for the success of this deal? If it does materialize, how can I ensure that I remain humble? I genuinely wish for this opportunity to come to fruition, but if it does not, I believe I will be at peace with that, as it may be the Lord protecting me from the person I could become with wealth. I am uncertain about how to navigate these feelings.

I experienced a healing miracle in January 2023, I suffered a SAH & was told an aneurysm was detected. My insurance would not approve an MRI, after being med flighted to UT medical center and was admitted in Neuro ICU for 10 days.  So the Neuro Surgeon that I was referred to after I was released, ordered an MRI. On Friday I went to have the MRI scan, on Sunday I attended a prayer service at Preaching Christ Church, they placed hands on me and prayed over me. When I left the church that day, my head had stopped hurting for the 1st time since the incident, and that lifted my spirit of belief, I prayed for my brain to heal and if my journey was not over, I would do everything that I can to help make the world a better place. On Monday I visited the doctor to get the MRI results, and he said "I dont know how this is possible, but there is no sign of aneurysm in your brain, it's clear."
Yes, a miracle or a misdiagnosis, I don't know, I believe that God saved me,  for a reason , I have a purpose. That experience transformed me, I have always had a strong faith in Christ, but now, I am filled with the spirit , I want to share love, joy and hope with others. I had a vision of what I can do to help my community , its a project that would help families and children in our country. The Kingsport Kingdom Center is a vision of a place for gatherings, social connection, and physical activity. I am reluctant to share the details, but I would be glad too with you. I would love to talk with you and share my story, I believe God is giving me the courage to message you, and email all the leaders that I have trying to get this project off the ground. 
Please if you can help direct me in the way to go?
 I also work as an independent contractor as a Notary signing agent. I do closings and signings for mortgage and title companies. I started that business after my brain blew up, and it's growing rapidly. I may have to set up an LLC for tax purposes. I would call my business  A+Agent . 
I have a prayer website called Aspiringinspiration.com through hostinger but its not showing up live, I am trying to troubleshoot. 

The Kingsport Kingdom Center is the project that I believe will unite churches, schools and organizations in our communities, it will bring people together. 
 It's needed and necessary.  Please help! Be an agent of change, help lead others, introducing the love of Jesus Christ.

I'm 45, married with no kids but care for my elderly parents who now live with me. Combined annual income of 110k and monthly expenses of  about 5k. We were doing good financially but things have taken a turn in the last 7 months. Big medical issues for both parents including dad who has cancer. Even with insurance and grants, his copays for treatments are multiple thousands and he has 3 each month. Add private nursing care, meds, etc and things are getting uncomfortable very quickly. Our savings are almost fully gone and we've started cutting expenses, but things are still extremely tight. Can't borrow against 401k in my state (state retirement system). Going to sell parents home which they owe free and clear. That should yield about 110k. For our home, we urgently need an extra bathroom, especially with my dads medical needs as there have been several accidents when he needed the bathroom but it was occupied. 

So here are the options we're considering:
1. Sell our home. We would pocket 120k in equity after paying off our loan. Rent a home with an extra bathroom and pay maybe 1 yr of rent in advance. Then use income to build back additional savings. Once medical crisis is over, Use whatever is left out of the sell of both homes and other savings to buy a home. 

2. Sell our home. Use 120k from sale to buy cheap land and a prefab (mobile) home cash. Then use income to build back additional savings. Once medical crisis is over, we can buy or build something more permanent. 

3. Use the 100k from sell of parents home to reconfigure our home for an additional bathroom. This seems most risky because we aren't lowering any bills and will have less cash leftover. 

4. Any other option I'm not seeing. I will be open to almost anything (except not having my parents with me. That is not an option I'm willing to consider). 

Ultimately, we need to take some pressure off financially and be able to build our savings back up. And no disrespect to 3-6 months of savings but this situation has taught me that I need to have at least 1 yr expenses because it only takes one medical emergency to almost wipe you dry. Please share any insight you have on how we can move forward! Thank you!!

I am 41 married with 4 kids. We have zero debt, house and everything paid in full. Kids go to private school. Really didn’t follow you until a little while ago. 

I have multiple businesses that I run. Online stores, wholesale, launching new product line on Amazon and have other private labeling ventures that make good income. This is more a relationship question than money. Although they intersect. 

I have been married 13 years. My wife is very frugal and I am not. However, I would never put us in a situation where we couldn’t pay something. My goal for years has been to keep increasing my monthly income. Hence why I reinvest and spread out into other businesses. Sometimes with all the different avenues I have money coming it actually is hard for me to track my actual income. Not a bad issue to have but a headache around Feb when I get to go back and get everything for accountant.

For years I have felt like I was dragging my wife along. I straight told her at one point that it felt like I was dragging an anchor. One of the things that drew me to her was how driven she was to save and get a house. But once we did that she felt like she made it. I felt like she could have tripped over the door step and still achieved that. 

She does stay home with the kids which I fully appreciate. She does her part there. I have got us to where the last year we averaged between 35-45k a month. We have around 450k in markets. Another 119k in her account and I have around 80k in mine. Plenty of money in the business accounts. So money isn’t the issue. 

The issue is I will get us to 80-100k a month. She is happy with where we are financially and wants me to be more involved with the kids. I set aside Saturday until 7pm to take the kids on my own so she gets a break. I also do go to their games not all but about half of them. They have games back to back because the older two managed to make middle school, JV and varsity. Plus my 9 year old has practice once a week. I also take them to mma, kickboxing and bjj. I personally do those too. I truly believe you have to lead by example. I can’t stand when parents tell their kids to do something they won’t. Especially when it comes to combat sports. 

So we are pretty busy. I don’t know how to get my wife on board with the vision when to her she was content with living a normal life. I think it embarrasses her a little the way I live. Paying off the house in 7 years, two additions along with an inground heated pool that I keep open all year up north. She doesn’t like the fact I have an extensive watch collection. I did legit buy 7 Rolex’s in about 10 months. I did get them retail from AD. So they are actually valued higher than I spent. I don’t drink, do drugs, have any interest in other women, no things that ruin most people’s marriage. 

My issue is everything gets filtered through my long term goal lens. Does this action get me closer to my goals? If it does I do it. If it doesn’t it gets disregarded. When it comes to her or success I know I pick the success financially every time. I have to fix that. I think eventually once the kids are grown we will end up split. Our visions of life are so far apart. She says she isn’t happy in this relationship. I would not be happy living like a normal person. I grew up poor and I swore to myself my children would never know what it is like to use a space heater because their parents can’t afford heating oil. 

That is not in me to ever live like that or anything close to what people call normal. All she wants is to be normal. She would be fine with us both working 9-5 as long as we got to spend time together each evening. I see that as throwing your life away. Aside from the mortgage balance, we have a combined roughly 60k in student loan debt and less than 5k in credit card debt.  We paid cash for our car last year when we stopped being stupid.

Housing costs in our area are high and rising.  For a 3br in a decent area with good schools near us we’re looking at about 300k on the low end.  We’re preapproved for a mortgage up to 350k.

Our plan was to stay in the condo for another couple of years to milk our low housing expenses (1500/mo), but the space just isn’t working for us (especially since I WFH) and I started to worry about rising housing prices forcing us out of the market in that time.

The alternatives were considering:

Sell the condo, buy a home with a mortgage that keeps our payments at 2200/mo or less (proving hard to find, but not impossible).  Use any remaining proceeds after closing costs (optimistically 20k) towards erasing as much debt as we can and chipping away at it from there.

Sell the condo, find a rental (cheapest 3brs around us are about 2500/mo).  Use condo proceeds (roughly 80k) to erase our 65k debts and put the rest towards rent.  Wipe the slate clean.  Save everything we can for a year towards a house and trying to make up for lost time with investing/retirement.  Rising housing costs would still be a concern, as would the timetable to save a down payment.

Both options are attractive and scary all at once.

Hey Ramsey and Team!
I'm 30, freshly married with 1 newborn living in germany. I am seeing your content mostly on YouTube, not everything is applying to us (universal Healthcare which is not bound to your job so no surprise expenses there, workers protection so your job is quite secure, free education so I barely know people who go into debt studying  and especially a different cultute towards creditcards and debt make it so you hardly go into debt at all, I think I only know people in debt for housed & car leases), but i really like your general way of thinking about finances and like to get insight from you and your team! 
About us, me and my wife just bought a house for 263k€ + are renovating it now for probably another 100k.
Currently we owe 150k on the house for buying it + the renovation money is coming from my salary / family will lend us interest free money for that (for the bigger purchases) and we have around 25k saved still.
Payments are 656€/month, and I can pay off 7500€ additional per year. (You cannot really within the contract pay off more earlier here)
We moved to my family's village to have the support with the kid and an affordable house with garden etc. 
I make about 5k net a month + my wive currently gets 1800€/month from the health insurance/state for taking care of our child in the first year (elterngeld), plus I think 255€ for child support(kindergeld)  from the state until the little one has his education or is 25years old.
We are otherwise debt free, we don't own credit cards.
I'm paying into state pension(~670€) + have a pension plan that is taking 185€ from my gross pay, so the 5k net is fully available.
When moving into the village, we needed a car (we only had a campervan before which we also used to travel your beautiful country in 2023!). I am driving 150km/90miles a day 3 times a week to work, so we got a VW ID3 for 25k€ paid cash for getting to work (gas prices in Germany are above California levels) 
Now we are looking for a 2nd car so my wife can be mobile when I'm not working from home (for basics like going to the doctor or getting groceries etc.) 
My dream car is a BMW E30 from the mid to end 80s. these cars have increased in value in the last 10 years nearly doubled, parts are available and affordable (here in Germany, probably not true for the US as much) and getting a car older than 30 years is lowering taxes and insurance on it.
Would you say it's wise to get a car like that priced at around 10k, or would you rather buy a car for ~3-4k that probably doesn't have resale value in 5 years? 
As we are currently in the state of "renovations around the corner" any car purchase will simply cut into directly paid off renovations and add to family loans.
One thing to add: I know that you often are not a fan of family loans. My sister did the same with my family and my parents did with theirs, my aunt did the same etc. the family overall is not rich at all but doing quite well and money is not a topic for us except for supporting each other to buy a house to live in. I am not concerned about the family situation.
Thanks for reading all that for a simple question and a lot of love from Germany, I hope to travel the US again once the kids are out of the house :D

10 years ago, I bought my first house. 7ish years ago, my finances were "messy" and I had $10K* in CC debt. I had ok credit, but I wanted to improve my score to gain benefits/discounts through different programs/financing.  I self educated using Google, and YouTube. I found a few content creators that explained how to used credit cards, to earn rewards, and increase your credit score. At the time, I had maybe 3 cc's, and over the course of a couple years on my journey to a Perfect score, I acquired 20* more cc's. I was using them only to buy what I would already buy, and everything was going great! My highest Credit Score was 847! What an incredible feeling!! 

I had been working in the manufacturing industry, as an hourly production worker for a lot of years. May 5th of 2020, I was terminated. I wasn't happy anymore. I spent a couple months soul searching, trying to figure out what I wanted to do professionally. Some of the people I followed on you tube, were Realtors, or had been, and it appeared to be a very rewarding career. So, I took a course, and joined Keller Williams. It WAS the best job I've ever had! I loved everything about it. It was nothing like what I expected, and it was very exciting. I sold real estate for 4 years, and did OK financially, and I had never been happier. But, I want a family, and the partners I had chosen to pursue over the next few years seemed to love my career from afar, until they realized its a lot of days, nights, weekends, holidays, and spur of the moment showings. A family is more important too me than my career, so I took an hourly sales job, which has a consistent M-F schedule, and chose not to renew my license. I had started justifying taking on debt, telling myself it was ok, because it was for my partners kids, or it was ok because I'm investing in the future of the relationship, or that it'll be ok because "we'll" figure it out. that relationship ended September 2023, and her and her kids moved out of my home. In hindsight, the relationship needed to end, I wasn't happy with the relationship, I just didn't want to lose her kids. Now I was again solely responsible for all household bills, and my personal debt which was now around $80k in CC debt. I was struggling with my mental health, and was going to sell my house to pay off my debt, to essentially be homeless, because I was so overwhelmed. I got to the point where I had to admit to myself that I could not afford to keep up with all my poor decisions, so when my bank account started to decline my CC payments, I stopped paying everything, except my mortgage, and what I deemed as essentials. 

In late 24' I received a letter from a company I used to work for, telling me that I'm now eligible to request payment of my employee stock. I opted for payment, and have received half of it $42k (the other half to be paid out next year.  Upon receiving this letter, and check, I gained some clarity/awareness of the last 12 months since stopping all debt repayments. I hadn't made any attempt to pay off any cc debt, and it made me feel sick to my stomach.

I decided to fix up my house, and replace the roof. so far I've spent approximately $5,000 getting some work done, and have my roof scheduled to be replaced (estimate $15k).

My plan is to sell the house, pay off all my debt, and reset in a warmer climate (MN native, want to move to south). A realtor that I will likely use, is suggesting a list price of $280K, and I owed $115K. A friend of mine who I often lean on for big decisions, as he's someone that I look up to, and has what I want, does not think its a good idea to sell my house to pay off my cc debt. FYI he is a real estate investor, has several properties, and is an advocate of Dave Ramsey and Financial Peace University. He told me he wanted to gift me FPU, and I told him that I could afford it....  was $80k in cc debt, and I could afford it. I've reflected on this, and now understand how absurd my thinking can be. 

I have built my own Finance tracker which tracks monthly, quarterly, and annual, and started using it a few months ago, and it was surprising to see some trends (manic spending), and just to see where my money goes.

I've also been able to recognize some of my spending patterns/thought processes,  and believe I have Learned to be a "consumer", and I don't want to be. I want to live free, be free, and love this life that I've been given.

So, should I sell my house to pay off all other debt, and reset? Or should I keep my house and pay off all debt more slowly?

I've been selling everything I own, and it feels really good to just get rid of stuff. I had never really done an inventory of my belongings. This has also made me feel sick, as It brings awareness to my spending habits.

I have no car payment, and no mobile device payment.

$80k in CC debt
$150K in home equity
$35K in the bank

$70K annual income
Single, no kids, 1 Taco Supreme (10 year old Boxer dog)

Drive an 2006 Prius (no payment)

I eat after they go to bed and it's something like soup because I want them to have something nice to eat, this does not bother me and I do not feel like I'm going hungry, but she is right I do not eat with them because I didn't want to them to notice I am eating something different. I want to sell my rent to own contract to give us a little safety net and maybe a newer car. My house is worth 250,000. I am very worried about this coming summer as I do not get paid for summer and cannot send the kids to childcare because its more than I make anyway. I'm up at 5:45 every day and in bed at 11PM.  Last summer I didn't have money for food and needed to use a food pantry, I almost lost my car but randomly (an answered prayer) the state of NY gave all SpED Preschool teachers and bonus, and I used it to pay off the car. My credit is 618.  How do I fix this mess that I made?  Some roadblocks are: I cannot move out to my children's school district, i cannot go back to court (ive already spent 62,000 at the time of divorce), and I cannot afford childcare.  and I assure you have ZERO interest in ever dating in order to have two incomes.
